channel.title: ANT 6973: Data Visualization and Exploration on ANT 6973, Spring 2019
channel.description: Recent content in ANT 6973: Data Visualization and Exploration on ANT 6973, Spring 2019

item.description: ANT 6973 DataCamp Dashboard Throughout the course we will be using DataCamp, a platform that provides an interactive way to learn how to use R to create visualizations and carry out data analysis. Invite link: https://www.datacamp.com/groups/shared_links/860db90029f1891286789d3ece4f95d11df40484

warning clear Please note: Syllabus content will be updated frequently as we progress through the topics. Date Topics Readings Assignments Slides Projects R, RSTUDIO, AND THE TIDYVERSE 2019-01-17 Introduction & Setup 2019-01-24 R Basics and R Markdown DATA VISUALIZATION 2019-01-31 Visualization Basics 2019-02-07 Visualizing Amounts and Parts of a Whole 2019-02-14 Visualizing Distributions and Uncertainty 2019-02-21 Visualizing Relationships and Change Over Time 2019-02-28 Color, Output, and Geospatial Data DATA MANIPULATION 2019-03-07 Data Import 2019-03-14 No class: Spring Break 2019-03-21 Reshaping Data 2019-03-28 No class: AAPA Conference 2019-04-04 Data Manip.

item.title: Policies
item.description: Course Description This course introduces theory and practical skills for managing and displaying quantitative information so that visual stories can be found and communicated effectively. We will cover principles of tidy data, strategies for data exploration, and principles of visual presentation. We will use the R computing environment, but no prior programming experience is required. The emphasis is on gaining practical skills that will empower students to answer questions with data.
ANT 6973

R and RStudio Basics code{white-space: pre;} pre:not([class]) { background-color: white; } if (window.hljs) { hljs.configure({languages: []}); hljs.initHighlightingOnLoad(); if (document.readyState && document.readyState === "complete") { window.setTimeout(function() { hljs.initHighlighting(); }, 0); } } h1 { font-size: 34px; } h1.title { font-size: 38px; } h2 { font-size: 30px; } h3 { font-size: 24px; } h4 { font-size: 18px; } h5 { font-size: 16px; } h6 { font-size: 12px; } .

tutorial for Data Science Triad: GitHub, RMarkdown, Travis-CI rstudio Watch: - RStudio IDE, Part I Read: readings/setup.md - Prerequisites - Running R code - RStudio Cheat sheet (for reference) rmarkdown Watch: Reports with RMarkdown (by Garrett Grolemund) Read: Introduction [r4ds-27.1] R Markdown [r4ds-27.2] Code chunks [r4ds-27.4] git Watch: DataCamp Lesson: RStudio IDE, Part II, Chapter 2: Version Control (by Garrett Grolemund). vis.1 Watch: Tidyverse Chapter 2: Data Visualization (David Robinson) (Yes, we’re starting with Chapter 2, we’ll go back to Chapter 1 soon).

item.title: Cheat Sheets
item.description: RStudio RStudio is a popular software application that provides a user-friendly interface for using R. RStudio make it easier to write and run code, organize your work into projects, and manage packages (among many other things). This cheat sheet describes some of the most useful features of RStudio. Data Visualization The ggplot2 package will be our primary tool for creating plots in this course. See ggplot2.

item.title: Color, Saving Output, and Geospatial Data
item.description: Read Making Effective Use of Color Wilke, Ch. 4: Color scales Wilke, Ch. 19: Common pitfalls of color use Saving Plots as Image Files R4DS, Ch. 28.7: Saving your plots Visualizing Geospatial Data Why all world maps are wrong XKCD Map Projections XKCD Heatmap Wilke, Ch. 15: Visualizing geospatial data Color Resources Color Brewer: Color advice and a great set of color palettes; r package: RColorBrewer.

item.title: Color, Saving Output, and Geospatial Data
item.description: 07_color-output-spatial.pdf ( 4.2 MB)

item.title: Data Import
item.description:
To complete this week’s activities, you will need two new packages. install.packages("here") install.packages("janitor") Complete in Class Paths Instructions: Download the zip file paths-project.zip and unzip the contents into this week’s folder. Open the project called paths-project.Rproj. Open the R Markdown file located at paths-project/rmd/paths.Rmd. Go through the activity, changing code where appropriate. Nothing to turn in!
paths-project.

item.title: Data Import
item.description: Read Organizing Data “Tidy Data” by Hadley Wickham. Don’t pay much attention to any R code you encounter, as most of it has now been superseded by newer tidyverse functions. This was Wickham’s early “tidy tools” manifesto; it provided guiding principles and a framework for developing the tidyverse. Peruse the website “Data Organization in Spreadsheets”, much of which has been written up in a journal article:

item.title: Data Import
item.description: 08_data-import.pdf ( 4.0 MB)

item.title: Data Manipulation 1
item.description: To complete this week’s activities, you will need to install the “development” version of tidyr. devtools::install_github("tidyverse/tidyr") Important note: As we discussed in class on March 21, the wide/long reshaping functions were in flux when we learned about them. Since that time, the authors have settled on slightly different names: pivot_longer() and pivot_wider(). It looks like these names are going to stick. All course materials have been updated accordingly.

item.title: Data Manipulation 1: Filter, Select, Arrange, Mutate
item.description: Read R4DS, 5.1–5.5: Data Transformation: dplyr basic verbs: filter, arrange, select, and mutate. Optional further reading. Introduction to dplyr: many code examples Modern Dive, Chapter 4: Data Wrangling: Similar to assigned reading but organized differently. Might be a little easier to follow?

item.title: Data Manipulation 2
item.description: Companion to in-class activities summarise-activities.Rmd (Nothing to turn in!)

item.title: Data Manipulation 2: Grouped Summaries, Filters, and Mutates
item.description: Read R4DS, 5.6–5.7: Data Transformation: dplyr basic verbs: summarise, group_by, and new ways to use mutate and filter. Optional further reading (same as last week). Introduction to dplyr: many code examples Modern Dive, Chapter 4: Data Wrangling: Similar to assigned reading but organized differently. Might be a little easier to follow?

item.title: Final Project
item.description:
Due date: May 05 by the end of the day (11:59:59 pm)
Description The final project should essentially look like any of our small projects, but with two key differences: You will decide on the data set to use, and I especially encourage you to find and/or use a data set that is related to your thesis topic. If this is not possible, I can help you find a data set on a topic relevant to your interests.

item.description: Complete in Class DataCamp Lesson: RStudio IDE, Part I, Chapter 1: “Orientation” (by Garrett Grolemund).

item.description: Read Preface of Healy’s Data Visualization.

item.title: Joins
item.description:
To complete this week’s activities, you will need to install the package nycflights13. Do this in console, not in your R Markdown file! install.packages("nycflights13") Companion to in-class activities two-table-operations.Rmd (Nothing to turn in!)
Complete before next class NYC Flights Instructions: Download the R Markdown file and data files below Insert your code where indicated Email me your knitted .

item.title: Modules
item.description: Module Candidate paper Data Format Technical skills timeline Climate Change Petit et al. (1999) Tabular data Parsing tabular data, visualization (readr, ggplot2) directions_boat Overfishing Worm et al. (2006) Relational databases groups, joins, filters. SQL (dplyr, tidyr) bug_report Ecological Simulations May (1974) memory Simulated data Functional programming, (purrr) my_location Range shifts Pinsky et al.

item.title: Modules
item.description: Climate Change Tabular data What is the evidence for a changing climate? In this unit, we will examine some of the most important indicators of global climate change: including CO2 concentration, global mean temperature, sea level rise, land ice sheet melt, and arctic sea ice cover. We will wrangle a wide range of tabular data file formats used by NOAA and other agencies and introduce the fundamentals of data visualization with ggplot2 and data processing with basic functions from the readr, tidyr, and dplyr packages as we seek to replicate the principle results of climate change over the last decades and also the past thousands of years.

item.title: R and RStudio Basics
R and RStudio Basics
item.description: Read ModernDive Ch. 2: Getting Started with Data in R Healy Section 2.3: Things to know about R Healy Section 2.4: Be patient with R, and with yourself Tidyverse style guide, Ch. 1 and Ch. 2. Consistent style is an important element of communication and collaboration. Skim over the sections 1. Files and 2. Syntax. Don’t worry if you don’t understand the code examples. Just try to get a feel for the style recommendations (e.

item.title: Reshaping Data
item.description: To complete this week’s activities, you will need to install the “development” version of tidyr. devtools::install_github("tidyverse/tidyr") Important note: As we discussed in class on March 21, the wide/long reshaping functions were in flux when we learned about them. Since that time, the authors have settled on slightly different names: pivot_longer() and pivot_wider(). It looks like these names are going to stick. All course materials have been updated accordingly.

item.title: Reshaping Data
item.description: 09_reshaping-data.pdf ( 3.3 MB)

item.title: Small Project 1: Ape Teeth
item.description:
Due date: Feb. 28 by the end of the day (11:59:59 pm) Introduction In this small project, you will think of conceptual questions to ask of a data set of ape teeth measurements and create plots to answer those questions.
Description of the data Download: - ape_teeth.csv Data source: http://anthropologicaldata.free.fr/ Columns Species: ape species the tooth belongs to, including: Gorilla gorilla (Western gorilla) Pan troglodytes (Common chimpanzee) Pongo pygmaeus (Bornean orangutan) Site: where specimen is located Specimen: specimen ID number Sex: Male or Female Source: where data come from Tooth: name of tooth (see below).

item.title: Small Project 2
item.description: Due date: Apr. 18 by the end of the day (11:59:59 pm) Introduction In this small project, you will think of conceptual questions to ask of one or more data sets. Because I think some of you disliked the ape_teeth data set from small project 1, this time I’m providing several different data sets that can be used. All your questions can be from one data set, or you can ask different questions of different data sets.

item.title: Two-table Operations: Joins and Set operations
item.description: Read Modern Dive, Chapter 4.7: “Join Data Frames”: A concise overview of join verbs in dplyr. R4DS, 13: Relational Data: More detailed, with many examples. Also covers set operations.

item.title: Visualization Basics
item.description: Complete in Class Mammalian sleep dataset: msleep Instructions: Download the R Markdown file below, insert your code where indicated, and send me your edited .Rmd file and knitted .html output as email attachments. msleep.Rmd msleep.html (for reference only) Complete on your own time between now and class on Feb. 07 Chapters 1–4 of Data Visualization with ggplot2 (Part 1) by Rick Scavetta. Chapter 1: “Introduction” Chapter 2: “Data” Chapter 3: “Aesthetics” Chapter 4: “Geometries” If you get stuck, feel free to email me or come by my office for some guidance.

item.title: Visualization Challenges
item.description:
Catch-up work Work on Small Project 2! Get caught up will any other assignments that you haven’t completed. This includes: 9 DataCamp chapters. msleep pies baboon-activities babynames maps ozone spreadsheets tidy-data data-manip1 If you’re all caught up, practice your data manipulation and plotting skills by working on the two small challenges below. I’ll post solutions after class is over.
1. Sex differences in mortality over time in Western Europe Data:

item.title: Visualizing Amounts and Parts of a Whole
item.description: Complete in Class Pie Chart Practice Instructions: Download the R Markdown file below, insert your code where indicated, and send me your knitted .html output as an email attachment. No need to send the .Rmd file! pies.Rmd Baboon Activity Budgets (if we run out of time, complete between now and class on Feb. 14) Instructions: Download the R Markdown file below, insert your code where indicated, and send me your knitted .

item.title: Visualizing Amounts and Parts of a Whole
item.description: Read Wilke, Ch. 6: Visualizing Amounts Wilke, Ch. 10: Visualizing Proportions Wilke, Ch. 11: Visualizing Nested Proportions Kristin Henry (2017) “In Defense of Pie Charts, and Why You Shouldn’t Use Them.” Robert Kosara (2016), “Stacked Bars Are the Worst.” “What to consider when creating stacked column charts.”

item.title: Visualizing Distributions and Uncertainty
item.description: Data for in-class activities Body Mass of Late Quaternary Mammals Instructions: Download the R Object file to use during the in-class activities. Nothing to turn in! late-quaternary-mammals.RDS Between now and class on Feb. 21 Get caught up will past DataCamp and in-class activities! Start thinking about Small Project 1.

item.title: Visualizing Distributions and Uncertainty
item.description: Read Wilke, Ch. 7: Visualizing distributions: Histograms and density plots Wilke, Ch. 9: Visualizing many distributions at once Wilke, Ch. 16: Visualizing uncertainty Popovich and Pearce, “It’s Not Your Imagination. Summers Are Getting Hotter.” Matthew Conlen, “Kernel Density Estimation” Nicole Torres (2010), “Why It’s So Hard for Us to Visualize Uncertainty” Robert Kosara (2017), “Communicating Uncertainty When Lives Are on the Line” Nathan Yau (FlowingData): “Showing uncertainty during the live election forecast”” (and a humorous critique of the NYT election uncertainty dial).

item.title: Visualizing Geospatial Data
item.description: Complete and Submit Before Class On Mar. 7 Maps Instructions: Follow the instructions at the bottom of this page under the heading “Extra Software and R Packages for Geospatial Data”. These steps should install the necessary software for spatial data visualization. Download the .zip file of data below, and unzip the file into this week’s folder. Download the R Markdown file below, insert your code where indicated, and email me your knitted .

item.title: Visualizing Relationships and Change Over Time
item.description: Complete in Class and Submit Baby Names Instructions: Download the R Markdown file below, insert your code where indicated, and email me your knitted .html output. No need to send the .Rmd file! To complete this assignment, you must install the babynames package: install.packages("babynames") babynames.Rmd babynames-solutions.html (for reference—finished plots with no code!) For Reference Only (nothing to turn in!) Katrina Instructions: Just look at it!

item.title: Visualizing Relationships and Change Over Time
item.description: Read Wilke, Ch. 12: Visualizing associations among two or more quantitative variables Wilke, Ch. 13: Visualizing time series and other functions of an independent variable Wilke, Ch. 14: Visualizing trends Nathan Yau, “11 Ways to Visualize Changes Over Time – A Guide” Keiran Healy, “Two Y-Axes” Stephanie Evergreen, “Two Alternatives to Using a Second Y-Axis”
